section.h2: Top played tracks from the last month

section.div: Favorites genres: Action, Comedy, Fantasy, Drama, Romance

div.div: The second season of Mairimashita! Iruma-kun. Suzuki Iruma, human and deeply non-aggressive, one day becomes the grandson of the great demon Sullivan. Doted on beyond belief, Iruma starts school where "Grandpa" serves as the chair... and finds, to his surprise, that he enjoys life there with Asmodeus, Clara, and the rest of his demon classmates. But just when Iruma thought he'd fitted in, there's more trouble ahead! A ring begins to talk, and Iruma... goes bad?! Iruma's chaotic, demonic life at school continues! (Source: NHK)

Nearly a century after magic was recognized as a real form of technology, Miyuki Shiba begins her term at Magic High School. An “honor” student, she dreamed of enjoying school with her older brother Tatsuya, an “irregular” student. But a rift between the gifted Course 1 students and the inferior Course 2 students could stand in the way. This time, Miyuki is the star of the show!
(Source: Funimation)
Shinka no Mi: Shiranai Uchi ni Kachigumi Jinsei

Hiiragi Seiichi is an ugly, revolting, dirty, smelly fatass; these are the insults hurled at him one after another about his appearance. Such was Seiichi's daily school life of bullying, then for some reason, one day when school was out, a voice claiming to be a God said over the PA system to prepare to be transported to another world. What's more, not Seiichi alone, but the entire school. A fantasy world where game-like elements such as as levels, stats, and skills exist. However, the God still had preparations to complete for the transfer, and would send them over as soon as the hero summoning ritual was ready. The classes all formed groups to wait for the transfer, but Seiichi alone was discluded and as such was summoned to a different area. After being transported the first thing Seiichi ate was the "Fruit of Evolution." This would come to greatly change his life...
This story is about how Seiichi went from being severely bullied by his classmates, even not being recognized for his accomplishments, and despite all that staying positive and surviving in this new world. As a result, he somehow becomes one of the champions. (Also the first heroine is a Gorilla?!)

When the duke was a young boy, a witch made it so that any living thing he touched died. Unable to cope with such a cursed child, his family sent him away to live in an old mansion. Now a young man, his only companions are an elderly butler and his childhood friend, a buxom, blonde maid named Alice. Despite the fact that touching the duke means instant death, Alice is constantly teasing him, getting close and flirting mercilessly. But even though Alice loves to make the duke blush, her affection for him is the real deal. Can the two figure out a way to break the witch’s spell? (Source: Seven Seas Entertainment) Note: The chapter count includes 15 extra chapters.
How do you use Aeron MDS with multiple publishers and a single subscriber where the publishers are unaware of the subscriber machine IPs?

I am trying to use Aeron Multi-Destination-Subscriptions where I have multiple publishers publish messages to their own IP address and port. I want a subscriber to subscribe to each of the publishers IP addresses and PORTs on the same stream ID. The publishers and subscribers are on separate machines. For simplicity, I'm testing this with a single Publisher and Subscriber setup. I am using docker to create a virtual network so I can designate the IPs of the publisher and subscriber machines. Here is my example code: Publication code final String publicationChannel = new ChannelUriStringBuilder() .media(UDP_MEDIA) (3 more lines were trimmed) Subscription code final String subscriptionChannel = new ChannelUriStringBuilder() .media(UDP_MEDIA) (8 more lines were trimmed) I have a doWork in both of these which repeatedly call subscription.isConnected() and publication.isConnected(). I expected this to work just like the MDC example where you can use control-mode=manual on the publication side and call publication.addDestination(subscriberIP:port) where the subscription would be setup to subscribe to its own subscriberIP:port. In testing, the publication and subscription are not connected. This test class in the aeron repo uses MDS over UDP using localhost and using multicast addresses MDSTest so I thought the same would hold true for using the publisher machines IP and port. Would really appreciate if someone could explain why this doesn't work?
